message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Offline Reinforcement Learning: Tutorial, Review, and Perspectives on Open Problems
Paper Abstract: In this tutorial article, we aim to provide the reader with the conceptual tools needed to get started on research on offline reinforcement learning algorithms: reinforcement learning algorithms that utilize previously collected data, without additional online data collection. Offline reinforcement learning algorithms hold tremendous promise for making it possible to turn large datasets into powerful decision making engines. Effective offline reinforcement learning methods would be able to extract policies with the maximum possible utility out of the available data, thereby allowing automation of a wide range of decision-making domains, from healthcare and education to robotics. However, the limitations of current algorithms make this difficult. We will aim to provide the reader with an understanding of these challenges, particularly in the context of modern deep reinforcement learning methods, and describe some potential solutions that have been explored in recent work to mitigate these challenges, along with recent applications, and a discussion of perspectives on open problems in the field.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for **Offline Reinforcement Learning**:

## Overview

Offline (or "batch") RL considers learning a policy from a fixed dataset without additional interaction with the environment. This contrasts with traditional reinforcement learning approaches that require continuous interaction with an environment.

## General Context

Offline learning is a machine learning training approach in which a model is trained on a fixed dataset that is not updated during the learning process, with the dataset collected beforehand and learning typically occurring in batch mode.

## Applications

Researchers have explored the use of offline RL in NLP to improve dialogue systems without the need of live human interaction, optimizing for user engagement, coherence, and diversity based on past conversation logs and pre-trained reward models.

## Related Concepts

In the context of reinforcement learning more broadly, an important distinction exists between on-policy algorithms that require evaluating or improving the policy that collects data, and off-policy algorithms that can learn a policy from data generated by an arbitrary policy, with value-function based methods such as Q-learning being better suited for off-policy learning.

## Web Search Results for Reinforcement Learning

Here's a comprehensive overview of Reinforcement Learning based on the search results:

### Definition and Core Concept

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

### How It Works

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

### Key Applications

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

### Major Advances

AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

## Search Results for Deep Reinforcement Learning

I found comprehensive information about Deep Reinforcement Learning. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition and Overview

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.(no content)Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

### How It Works

Deep RL algorithms are able to take in very large inputs (e.g. every pixel rendered to the screen in a video game) and decide what actions to perform to optimize an objective (e.g. maximizing the game score).

### Applications

Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

### Notable Achievements

In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics. More specifically, AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

### Real-World Applications Beyond Games

In robotics, it has been used to let robots perform simple household tasks and solve a Rubik's cube with a robot hand. Deep RL has also found sustainability applications, used to reduce energy consumption at data centers.

Links: [{"title":"Decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Decision fatigue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_fatigue"},{"title":"Decision-making under deep uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_under_deep_uncertainty"},{"title":"Military Decision Making Process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_Decision_Making_Process"},{"title":"Memory and decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_and_decision-making"},{"title":"Models of judicial decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Models_of_judicial_decision_making"},{"title":"Data-informed decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data-informed_decision-making"},{"title":"Judgment and Decision Making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judgment_and_Decision_Making"},{"title":"Optimal decision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_decision"}]

I've completed a web search on "Decision Making" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In psychology, decision-making is regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief or a course of action among several possible alternative options.(no content)It could be either rational or irrational.

## Types of Decision-Making Approaches

**Rational vs. Intuitive**: In situations with higher time pressure, higher stakes, or increased ambiguities, experts may use intuitive decision-making rather than structured approaches, following a recognition-primed decision that fits their experience.

**Consensus-Based**: Consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.

**Data-Informed**: Data-informed decision-making (DIDM) refers to the collection and analysis of data to guide decisions and improve chances of success.

## Key Challenges

**Decision Fatigue**: Decision fatigue is the tendency for peoples' decision making to become impaired as a result of having recently taken multiple decisions.

**Analysis Paralysis**: Analysis paralysis is the state that a person enters where they are unable to make a decision, in effect paralyzing the outcome.

**Environmental Factors**: The decision-maker's environment can play a part in the decision-making process, as environmental complexity is a factor that influences cognitive function.

The search results provide extensive information on decision-making theories, practical applications, and psychological factors affecting how people make choices.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

**Analysis Paralysis**: Analysis paralysis is the state that a person enters where they are unable to make a decision, in effect paralyzing the outcome.

**Environmental Factors**: The decision-maker's environment can play a part in the decision-making process, as environmental complexity is a factor that influences cognitive function.

The search results provide extensive information on decision-making theories, practical applications, and psychological factors affecting how people make choices.

## Robotics Overview

I found comprehensive information about robotics. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Scope
Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

### Core Components
Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms. Robotics typically combines three main aspects:
- Mechanical construction: a frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task
- Electrical components that power and control the machinery, used for movement (through motors), sensing, and operation
- A program is how a robot decides when or how to do something

### Specialized Fields
The search results include several specialized areas of robotics:
- **Soft Robotics**: A subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.
- **Robotic Arms**: A type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.
- **Humanoid Robots**: Companies like Hanson Robotics develop human-like robots with artificial intelligence for various applications.

The field continues to grow, with increasing investment and applications in manufacturing, healthcare, research, and entertainment.

Links: [{"title":"Health care - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_care"},{"title":"Healthcare in Singapore - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare_in_Singapore"},{"title":"Healthcare in New York City - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare_in_New_York_City"},{"title":"Single-payer healthcare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-payer_healthcare"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in healthcare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_healthcare"},{"title":"Max Healthcare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Healthcare"},{"title":"UnitedHealth Group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UnitedHealth_Group"},{"title":"United Surgical Partners International - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Surgical_Partners_International"},{"title":"HCA Healthcare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCA_Healthcare"},{"title":"Category:Children's Healthcare of Atlanta - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Children's_Healthcare_of_Atlanta"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of healthcare:

## Definition and Scope

Healthcare is the improvement or maintenance of health via the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, amelioration or cure of disease, illness, injury, and other physical and mental impairments in people.(no content)Health care is delivered by health professionals and allied health fields.

## Healthcare Systems

A health system is the organization of people, institutions, and resources that deliver health care services to populations in need. Different countries have different healthcare models. For example:

- In some cases doctors are employed and hospitals are run by the government, such as in the UK or Spain, while alternatively, the government may purchase healthcare services from outside organizations, such as the approach taken in Canada.
- Singapore's healthcare mainly consists of a government-run publicly funded universal healthcare system as well as a significant private healthcare sector.

## Economic Impact

In the United States, the healthcare industry accounts for 18% of gross domestic product in 2020 and is one of the largest and most complex parts of the U.S. economy.

## Technology and Innovation

Artificial intelligence in healthcare is the application of artificial intelligence to analyze and understand complex medical and healthcare data, and in some cases, it can exceed or augment human capabilities by providing better or faster ways to diagnose, treat, or prevent disease.

Links: [{"title":"Education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education"},{"title":"An Education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/An_Education"},{"title":"Education in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Secondary education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secondary_education"},{"title":"United States Department of Education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Education"},{"title":"Category:Schools in Rizal (province) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Schools_in_Rizal_(province)"},{"title":"Undergraduate education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undergraduate_education"},{"title":"Thomas's London Day Schools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas's_London_Day_Schools"},{"title":"Category:Schools in Santo Domingo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Schools_in_Santo_Domingo"},{"title":"Category:Former West Coast Conference schools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Former_West_Coast_Conference_schools"}]

I've performed a web search for "Education" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

Education is the transmission of knowledge and skills and the development of character traits.(no content)Formal education occurs within a structured institutional framework, such as public schools, following a curriculum.

## Types of Education

Non-formal education also follows a structured approach but occurs outside the formal schooling system, while informal education involves unstructured learning through daily experiences.(no content)Formal and non-formal education are categorized into levels, including early childhood education, primary education, secondary education, and tertiary education.

## Education Levels

Secondary education covers two phases: Level 2 (lower secondary education) is the second and final phase of basic education, and Level 3 (upper secondary education) is the phase immediately preceding tertiary education.(no content)Undergraduate education is education conducted after secondary education and before postgraduate education, and typically includes all postsecondary programs up to the level of a bachelor's degree.

## Social Role

Education socializes children into society by instilling cultural values and norms, equipping them with the skills necessary to become productive members of society. In doing so, it stimulates economic growth and raises awareness of local and global problems.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Offline Reinforcement Learning: Tutorial, Review, and Perspectives on Open Problems" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper is classified as a **survey** because it's explicitly presented as a tutorial article that reviews existing work on offline reinforcement learning, describes challenges, and discusses solutions explored in recent research. It does not propose novel methods.

**Extracted Triples (7 total):**

1. **Offline learning** (concept) - The core subject of the paper
2. **Reinforcement learning** (concept) - The foundational paradigm
3. **Deep reinforcement learning** (concept) - The modern approach discussed
4. **Decision-making** (task) - The broader application domain
5. **Robotics** (task) - Key application domain
6. **Health care** (task) - Key application domain
7. **Education** (task) - Application domain

All triples have been:
- Properly mapped to Wikipedia articles
- Assigned appropriate entity types (3 concepts, 4 tasks)
- Marked with "uses" relation (as expected for a survey using existing work)
- Given relevant 1-sentence descriptions

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED - All checks passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Offline learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Offline_learning)
- [Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
